Award.AwardTitle: Using Anchoring Vignettes to Improve Measures of Teaching Practice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The accuracy of self report of teachers' perceptions of their instructional practices has been a limitation in research and evaluation in education. This project is using a mixed methodological approach to address the extent to which the use of vignettes of teachers engaging in six different instructional practices lead to more accurate teacher self-report on their own practices. Researchers from the Rand Corporation and others in partnership with the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation Measures of Effective Teaching Extension study will work with 220 teachers in grades 4-9. Research questions address the extent to which teachers understand the instructional practices being portrayed at different levels in the vignettes, the extent to which the use of anchoring vignettes improve teacher self-report , the extent to which information in the teachers' ratings of the vignettes can be used to improve the alignment of teachers' self-rating and expertly-trained raters observations of videos of these teachers, and how the vignette-calibrated teacher self-reports correlate with estimates of other outcomes of teaching such as student achievement or ratings of teachers. The research findings inform the research on the conditions of instructional practices and hold promise for effective feedback to teachers.

Researchers in this project have identified important instructional practices and have developed expert-vetted vignettes that describe several levels of the quality of the instantiation of these practices. This project leverages the work conducted in the Gates MET project and collects survey data and video of classroom teaching from a sample of those teachers. The teachers rank the teaching as described in the vignettes and this ranking is used to calibrate their self-reported rating of their own teaching from surveys. The analysis of teacher videos is be used to provide another measure of teachers' practices. The researchers use the calibrated survey ratings of teaching to correlate with outcomes of teaching including value-added models of student achievement and student and principal ratings to examine the extent to which the calibrated surveys can be used as robust measures of teaching.

Teacher evaluation as a policy area is an increasingly important theme in educational reform. The evaluation methodology that can provide more valid and reliable measures of teaching than simple self-report provides better evidence of the current educational practices. Better evidence of improvements in teaching practices as a result of selected professional development for teachers results in more-informed selection of those offerings. The findings from this study identify ways that robust information about teaching practices can been identified in cost-efficient ways that supplement the use of classroom observations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Improving teaching effectiveness has been hampered by the lack of information about what actually happens behind the classroom door. Teachers, at best, are observed infrequently by their supervisors. Systematic observation of daily teaching practices is virtually non-existent in America’s classrooms. Unfortunately, without more comprehensive information about the details of daily teaching practices, it is not possible to investigate the relationship between teaching practices and student success. The national goal of improving student achievement and attainment is blocked by this dearth of information about daily teaching practices. 

An often overlooked and much underutilized source of information about daily teaching practices are the teachers themselves. It is relatively inexpensive and unobtrusive to ask teachers through on-line surveys about the extent to which they engage in specific practices. However, previous attempts to validate teacher self-reports of their practices has shown a disturbing lack of correspondence of teacher self-reports with measures of practice created by external observers of the same teachers and classrooms. We seek to address this discrepancy between self-reported practice and observed practice by gathering additional information that can be used to aid in the interpretation of teacher self-reports. 

We examine two possible sources for the discrepancy between teacher self-reported practice and practice as measured by external observers. First, we investigate the possibility that the response scales used to collect information from teachers are subject to a variety of interpretations. Second, we investigate the possibility that teachers vary in their tendency to shade their responses to give a more favorable impression of their practice. We find evidence that both of these factors have an impact on the validity of teachers’ self-reports and develop methods to account for these sources of the discrepancy.

Researchers in other fields have used anchoring vignettes to account for variation among respondents in their interpretation of survey response scales. When respondents are asked to reply, say, on a scale of 1 – 5 about the extent to which they use a particular teaching practice, it is not surprising that a 4 might have a different interpretation among different teachers. Therefore, we asked all of the teachers in our sample to rate a few vignettes, or short descriptions, of teaching practice by hypothetical teachers using the same scale that they used to rate themselves. We then use their ratings of the common vignettes to adjust their self-ratings to a common scale, eliminating the imprecision due to individual interpretations of the scale values.

Prior research also has investigated ways for measuring explicit and implicit bias due to desirable responding. Survey respondents in many situations have been shown to vary in their tendencies to misrepresent reality, either because the respondent would like the survey administrator to have a favorable opinion of them or because the respondent actually believes that their practice is more favorable than it really is. In order to account for these two tendencies, we administer a validated survey instrument that captures both aspects of desirable responding, along with our survey of teaching practices. We then use the measures of desirable responding to further adjust the self-reported practices to account for these biases.

Our research demonstrates that both of these factors – scale interpretation and desirable responding – play a role in the discrepancy between self-reported practice and observed practice. Furthermore, we show that it is possible to use the ancillary information from vignette ratings and desirable response inventories to adjust self-reports and create more valid measures of teaching practice in a cost-effective manner. If more investigation supports the validity of our methods on a broader scale, then a wide application of these survey methods could lead to a large repository of teaching practice information that can be used with information on student outcomes to better understand what type of teaching practices are most important for the success of our youth.
